data.title: Book Around the Corner
data.meta_description: Posts about Portuguese literature written by Emma
data.text:
Ballad of Dogs Beach. Dossier of a Crime by Jos√© Cardoso Pires. (1982) French title: Ballade de la plage aux chiens. Translated by Michel Laban.

Jos√© Cardoso Pires (1925-1998) is a Portuguese writer and Ballad of Dogs Beach is his most renowned work. Please note that it was published in 1982, after the Carnation Revolution of April 25th, 1974, the military coup that overthrew Salazar‚Äôs dictatorship and brought democracy in Portugal.

Ballad of Dogs Beach is a crime fiction book about the workings of an investigation.

On April 4th, 1960, the corpse of Major Luis Dantas Castro is found dead on a beach. Dogs unburied his body and the police found that he was shot multiple times. A few months before, he had escaped from Fort Gra√ßa, the military prison in Elvas where he was kept after his condemnation for an aborted military coup. Two other military escaped with him, Caporal Bernardino and the architect and soldier Fontenova.

The book‚Äôs subtitle is Dossier of a Crime because it is like reading the file of the investigation led by Inspector Elias Santana, alias Graveyard. The PIDE, the political police, gets involved and the undercurrent competition between the criminal investigation team and the PIDE taints the way the investigation is done.

The police quickly arrest Dantas Castro‚Äôs lover, Mena. Santana keeps her detention a secret and interrogates her repeatedly until he knows everything that happened between the evasion from Fort Gra√ßa to the death of the Major in Lisbon. They understand early on that the four fugitives laid low in an isolated house and Santana is like a dog after a bone. He keeps asking Mena to repeat her story to recoup the details and catch any discrepancies in her narrative.

Step by step, we follow the investigation and sort of read a file that mixes what Mena says in her testimony, what Santana thinks, what he does to track down the truth and all the political intricacies handled by Otero, Santana‚Äôs boss. And the beautiful Mena becomes Santana‚Äôs obsession; he has lurid fantasies about her and meeting her for these interviews is more and more about spending time with her than uncovering new clues.

As the book progresses, we understand all the sordid details of the case, a fatal mix of lust, powerplay, double game and revolutionary idealism. On the English summary of the book on Goodread, it says it‚Äôs based on a true story. There‚Äôs no such information in French, not in the book, not on the author‚Äôs Wikipedia page or on French Goodreads.

That‚Äôs for the story. Now the literary form. It was a rather dense book to read, not something I could read quickly, even in French. I‚Äôve seen that the author is influenced by Modernism. Since I‚Äôm not a literature teacher, I don‚Äôt know. We glide from one scene to the other, in prison with Mena, outside in Santana‚Äôs world or with the runaways in their hiding place. There aren‚Äôt many dialogues as it is a patchwork of Santana‚Äôs investigation. How he interrogated Mena, how he corroborated and double-checked facts, how he reconstituted the events in his head.

Jos√© Cardoso Pires introduces a good dose of humor in his descriptions which lightens the mood. Otherwise, it‚Äôd be quite suffocating. The atmosphere is strained between the runaways as they are trapped in the house with no obvious way out and Mena and Castro‚Äôs volatile relationship adds fire to the mix. At the police headquarters, the criminal police must handle the case with care and navigate in troubled waters since the PIDE is involved.

The breath of fresh air also comes from Santana and his pet, Lizardo the Lizard, from the irony in the descriptions of Lisbon in 1960, even if we understand that the Salazar regime has run its course, that corruption is rampant and that Dantas Castro is right to wish for a change in the head of the military but his action comes too early. 1974 it will be.

A fascinating read but unlike a lot of crime fiction books, it‚Äôs not an entertaining Beach and Public Transport book. I wonder if Jos√© Cardoso Pires inspired L√≠dia Jorge when she wrote The Memorables.

PS: For the anecdote, I have a used copy and the price on the book is 68 francs as it was printed in 1999. It means it cost 10.37 euros in 1999 and if I want to buy a new copy today, it costs 10.55 euros. Optimist take: not a lot of inflation on this book in 24 years. Pessimist take: they‚Äôre still selling the batch printed in 1999.

I was happy to see that Cathy from 746 Books hosts her 20 Books Of Summer event again this year. I know I could pick 10 or 15 books instead of 20 but I‚Äôm going to challenge myself a bit, even if reading isn‚Äôt a competition.

Picking the 20 books is already a lot of fun. This year I chose books from my TBR and according to three categories: books I‚Äôll read as part of already set-up readalongs, books I want to read around my summer trip to Montana, Wyoming and South Dakota and other books from various countries, just for armchair travelling and making a dent in the TBR.

Books from my readalongs:

Ballad of Dogs‚Äô Beach by Jos√© Cardoso Pires (1982) ‚Äì Portugal. French title: Ballade de la plage aux chiens.

We‚Äôre in 1960 and a rebellious officer is found dead on a beach. He was killed after evading from prison with his girlfriend after an aborted coup. The novel is about his life and the investigation on his death.

L‚ÄôAutre by Andr√©e Chedid (1969) ‚Äì France. Not available in English

Andr√©e Chedid is a French poetess. When I browse through the book, I see it‚Äôs made of three short stories, that these stories include poems and texts with a weird layout. I‚Äôm curious about it.

The Moving Target by Ross McDonald (1949) ‚Äì USA. French title: Cible mouvante.

I‚Äôll finally read my first Lew Archer investigation! I‚Äôve read only good reviews about this series and in France it is published by Gallmeister in a new translation by the talented Jacques Mailhos.

The Catcher in the Rye (1951) ‚Äì USA. French title: L‚Äôattrape-coeurs.

I‚Äôve read it in French when I was a teenager. This time I‚Äôll read it in English. I wonder how I‚Äôll respond to it now that I‚Äôm older.

Letters to wilderness by Wallace Stegner ‚Äì USA. French title: Lettres pour le monde sauvage.

This is a collection of non-fiction essays by Wallace Stegner. I think these texts were put together by Gallmeister and translated by Anatole Pons-Reumaux. I‚Äôm not sure this exact collection exists in English. I‚Äôve read Crossing to Safety and Remember Laughter and I love his prose. I‚Äôm looking forward to reading his essays.

Books for my trip to Montana and Wyoming

An Unfinished Life by Mark Spragg (2004) ‚Äì USA. French title: Une vie inachev√©e.

I got this as a gift and I‚Äôve seen it has been made into a film with Robert Redford, Morgan Freeman and Jennifer Lopez. Here‚Äôs a excerpt of the blurb ‚ÄúAfter escaping the last of a long string of abusive boyfriends, Jean Gilkyson and her ten-year-old daughter Griff have nowhere left to go. Nowhere except Ishawooa, Wyoming, where Jean‚Äôs estranged father-in-law, Einar, still blames her for the death of his son.‚Äù

Justice by Larry Watson (1995) ‚Äì USA. French title: Justice.

I‚Äôve already read Montana 1948 and Justice is a prequel to it.

Spirit of Steamboat by Craig Johnson (2013) ‚Äì USA Not available in French.

A Christmas story with sheriff Longmire. Maybe it‚Äôll be a little strange to read a Christmas story in the summer. I don‚Äôt know, I‚Äôll let you know how that feels. üôÇ

Fall Back Down When I Die by Joe Wilkins (2019) ‚Äì USA French title: Ces montagnes √† jamais.

A young ranch hand has just lost his mother, owes a lot of money for her medical bills and his son‚Äôs cousin comes in his care. It sounds like a great story of a man and a little boy who both need a lot of TLC.

Savage Run by C.J Box (2003) ‚Äì USA French title: La mort au fond du canyon.

This is the second volume of the Joe Pickett series. It‚Äôs a perfect read for the 21 hours of travel from Lyon to Billings.

If Not For This by Pete Fromm (2014) ‚Äì USA French title: Mon d√©sir le plus ardent.

I‚Äôve read his novel A Job You Mostly Won‚Äôt Know to Do and his essay, Indian Creek Chronicles and a collection of short stories, Chinook. All were outstanding. Needless to say I‚Äôm looking forward reading another book by him.

Montana. La reconqu√™te de l‚ÄôOuest (2018) ‚Äì Belgium Not available in English.

This is a collection of essays about Montana‚Äôs history. It‚Äôs only 85 pages long, a short read then.

Armchair travelling and TBR management

Proud Beggars by Albert Cossery (1955) ‚Äì Egypt. French title: Mendiants et orgueilleux.

Albert Cossery (November 3, 1913 ‚Äì June 22, 2008) was an Egyptian-born French writer of Greek Orthodox Syrian and Lebanese descent, born in Cairo. Proud Beggards is set in Cairo but written in French.

Children of the Bitter River by Fang Fang (1987) ‚Äì China. Frencht title: Une vue splendide.

Fang Fang is a Chinese writer from Huhan and I‚Äôve never read her. Here‚Äôs the blurb of the book which ‚Äúnarrates a Chinese version of the Horatio Alger myth of a poor boy achieving fame and fortune. In addition to daunting poverty, the hero, Seventh Brother, must overcome the trauma of physical abuse. His story and that of his six brothers traces the history of China from the 1930s to the mid-1980s.

Ping-Pong by Park Min-kyu (2016) ‚Äì Korea Not available in English

I‚Äôve already read his Pavane for a Dead Princess but Ping-Pong seems a lot more playful. Two adolescents are bullied at school and they discover a field with a ping-pong table. It becomes their safe haven. They meet with Secr√©tin and strike a bet with him. The book mixes realism and science fiction.

Sputnik Sweethearts by Haruki Murakami (1999) ‚Äì Japan. French title: Les amants du spoutnik.

I have it in English on the kindle, perfect for travelling. I hope I‚Äôll like it as I‚Äôm not always fond of Murakami‚Äôs novels. We‚Äôll see.

The Fishermen by Chigozie Obioma (2015) ‚Äì Nigeria. French title: Les p√™cheurs.

I‚Äôm trying to read more African books and I picked this one a couple of years ago. Here‚Äôs the blurb: ‚ÄúIn a small town in western Nigeria, four young brothers take advantage of their strict father‚Äôs absence from home to go fishing at a forbidden local river. They encounter a dangerous local madman who predicts that the oldest boy will be killed by one of his brothers. This prophecy unleashes a tragic chain of events of almost mythic proportions.‚Äù

High Rising by Angela Thirkell (1933) ‚Äì UK. French title: Bienvenue √† High Rising.

This is another light read for planes and airports.

Gratitude by Delphine de Vigan (2019) ‚Äì France. Original French title: Les Gratitudes.

Another book that I have on the kindle. Delphine de Vigan never disappoints and I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôll enjoy it.

A Rising Man by Abir Mukherjee (2016) ‚Äì UK. French title: L‚Äôattaque du Calcutta-Darjeeling.

This is a book I bought at Quais du Polar. It‚Äôs the first instalment of the Sam Wyndham series set in colonial India.

The Gringo Champion by Aura Xilonen (2015) ‚Äì Mexico. French title: Gabacho

I remember where I bought this novel. It was in an indie bookstore in Barcelonnette, in the South of France. This town has a special relationship with Mexico as a lot of people emigrated to Mexico in the 19thcentury, became successful businessmen there and came back to their hometown and built sumptuous mansions. An incredible story.

So the local bookstore carries Mexican lit and I was drawn to The Gringo Champion, the story of a young Mexican boy who emigrate illegally in the US and tells his story as a clandestine.

That‚Äôs my list for the summer. Five books are on the Gallmeister catalogue and we‚Äôll go to Portugal, France, America, especially Montana and Wyoming, Egypt, China, Korea, Japan, Nigeria, UK and Mexico. That‚Äôs quite a tour!

Have you read any of these books? Will you be doing the 10 / 15 / 20 Books of Summer too?

Friendship Is a Gift You Give Yourself by William Boyle (2018) French title: L‚Äôamiti√© est un cadeau √† se faire. Translated by Simon Baril

This is my second book by William Boyle after The Lonely Witness and he‚Äôs definitely an author I want to keep reading.

Friendship‚Ä¶ is set in Brooklyn, in the Bronx and upstate New York. It all starts when Rena Ruggiero, the widow of a mafia gangster, kicks her eighty years old neighbor and thinks that she killed him as he lays unresponsive on her floor. High on Viagra, he tried to rape her.

Rena takes his car and drives to the Bronx where she wants to stay with her estranged daughter Adrienne and rekindle her relationship with her granddaughter Lucia.

She arrives there just as Richie Schiavano decides to steal money from a mafia gang.

Rena and Lucia find shelter at Adrienne‚Äôs neighbor‚Äôs house. Lacey, ex-porn star known as Lucious Lacey, welcomes them in her home and they end up fleeing the Bronx with the mafia on their tail.

The book takes a delightful Thelma and Louise turn and the reader is in for a fantastic ride.

William Boyle has a knack for a crazy plot, for attaching characters and an fantastic sense of place. A wonderful discovery by Gallmeister.

Alabama 1963 by Ludovic Manchette & Christian Niemiec (2020). Not available in English.

This is a French crime fiction novel set in Birmingham, Alabama in 1963, just before President Kennedy was assassinated and right in the middle of the Civil Right movement.

Girls are rapped and murdered. Bud Larkin, a white PI, former police officer, is volunteered to help a black family find out who killed their daughter. His former colleagues also hire him a black cleaning lady, Adela Cobb. In segregated Alabama, she‚Äôll be an asset to Larkin as black people talk to her but not to him.

As other murders happen, Bud and Adela get more and more anxious to find out who‚Äôs behind these crimes. And if this adventure can help them sort out their lives, all the better.

I‚Äôm always a bit suspicious about books written by French writers and set in America, written as if they were American writers. This one was OK, and the fact that the two authors‚Äô day job is to translate American TV series into French probably helps writing a convincing story. They know all the codes.

I had a good time reading it, I got attached to Adela and Bud.

As the Crow Flies by Craig Johnson (2012) French title: A vol d‚Äôoiseau. Translated by Sophie Aslanides.

This is the 8th volume of the Walt Longmire series. I read them in English now since the French paperbacks are no longer published by Gallmeister but by Pocket. The books aren‚Äôt as nice, so, the original on the kindle is better.

This time around, Caddy, Longmire‚Äôs daughter is getting married in two weeks on the Cheyenne reservation when Walt discovers that she no longer has a venue.

He‚Äôs on his way to visit another location with his friend Henry Standing Bear when they see a woman fall from a cliff and die. She had her six-month old baby in arms when she fell. The baby miraculously survived.

Walt Longmire will mentor the new chief of the Tribal Police, Lolo Long during this investigation. She‚Äôll learn a few tricks, soften some hard edges and see how to navigate the tricky relationship with the FBI. Very useful skills if she wants to keep her job or stay alive while doing it.

As always, Craig Johnson delivers. The plot is well-drawn, a part of fun is introduced with Lolo Long‚Äôs blunders and the relationship between Walt and Caddy is lovely. This volume is set on the Cheyenne reservation and it rings true, at least to my French ears.

Craig Johnson doesn‚Äôt disappoint and I‚Äôm looking forward to reading the ninth book.

S≈ìurs de sang by Dominique Sylvain (1997, reviewed by the author in 2010). Not available in English

I‚Äôve read several books by Dominique Sylvain. Kabuchiko, set in Japan, Les Infid√®les and Passage du D√©sir set in Paris. The three books are different and Soeurs de sang is closer to Passage du D√©sir than to the other ones.

We‚Äôre in Paris. Louise Morvan is a PI who is hired by Ana Chomsky to find a former lover that she spotted as a character in a video game. Louise starts investigating, discovers that he‚Äôs Axel Langeais, one of the creators of the game.

It could stop here but Victoria Yee, the lead singer of the group Noir Vertige is murdered on Axel‚Äôs barge, in front of his sister R√©gine. Louise embarks on a murder investigation that will lead her to Berlin and Los Angeles and into the strange artistic world of the Victim Art.

I read this with pleasure, a novel set in a very peculiar milieu, the one of extreme art and I was curious to see how the story would unfold.

Ames animales by JR Dos Santos (2021). Not available in English.

This was one of our Book Club choices and it was a promising read.

It‚Äôs a Portuguese novel set in Lisbon. The main character is Tomas Noronha whose wife Maria Flor is involved with a charity that works on animal intelligence. When the director of this charity is murdered, she‚Äôs the last one to have seen him and is accused of murder.

Chapters alternate between the crime plot and flash backs where the militant and director is enlightening Maria Flor about the latest researches about animal intelligence. These lengthy explanations were too didactical for me, cut the flow of the crime investigation and I lost interest.

I abandoned the book. I don‚Äôt read crime fiction to read scientific lectures, there are radio podcasts for that. A missed opportunity.

I have also read The Hot Spot by Charles Williams but this one is so good that it deserves its own billet.

Lisbon Poets. French title: Po√®tes de Lisbonne. Translated from the Portuguese by Elodie Dupeau.

This is the first billet of my 20 Books of Summer challenge, one of the ghosts of trips past. I bought the poetry collection Lisbon Poets during a trip to Lisbon. Obviously.

It‚Äôs a lovely bilingual edition of poems by Lu√≠s de Cam√µes, Ces√°rio Verde, M√°rio de S√°-Carneiro, Florbela Espanca and Fernando Pessoa. The same book exists in English, Italian, German and other languages.

The French translation is new, there‚Äôs a foreword by Anne-Marie Quint, professor at the Sorbonne. Original drawings by Andr√© Carrilho illustrate the book and all this attention to details makes of this edition a nice book to have in hands.

Now I‚Äôm not a great reader of poetry and imagine the challenge to write a billet in English about poems you‚Äôve read in a Portuguese/French bilingual edition. I‚Äôll be brief.

Poet seems to be a dangerous profession in Portugal if you look at these poets‚Äô untimely death. Except for Lu√≠s de Cam√µes who lived 56 years in the 16th century, they all died young. Ces√°rio Verde was 31 when he died in 1886, M√°rio de S√°-Carneiro was 26 when he committed suicide in 1916, Florbela Espanca was 36 when she killed herself in 1930 and at 47, Fernando Pessoa was an old man compared to the others when he died in 1935.

Bilingual editions of poetry are great, at least for western languages. I wouldn‚Äôt get anything out of a Japanese/French book but for Latin languages, it‚Äôs wonderful. Portuguese is a funny language for me as a French: when I read it, I recognize a lot of words but when I hear it, I don‚Äôt understand anything. Since I read the poems, having the original beside the French translation was a treat and useful.

I wasn‚Äôt so keen on Ces√°rio Verde and M√°rio de S√°-Carneiro. I found Verde a bit whiny and I disliked Feminina by M√°rio de S√°-Carneiro because I found it mysoginistic.

My favorite poems were by Lu√≠s de Cam√µes, Florbela Espanca and some by Fernando Pessoa. I loved Alma minha gentil, que tepartite by Cam√µes, a beautiful poem about his grief after his lover died. I enjoyed the sensuality in Florbela Espanca‚Äôs poems, her assertiveness as a woman. In A uma rapariga (To A Young Girl), she urges girls to live their life, to be bold and go for what they want. Fernando Pessoa‚Äôs poems are beautiful. I loved O livro de Ces√°rio Verde, his others full of thoughts about life.

I‚Äôm aware that my comments are trite but think again of my challenge here. Even in French, I would struggle to have anything clever to say about poems, so in this context, it‚Äôs even worse. I‚Äôll stop then and urge you to get this little gem if you ever go to Portugal. It seems like a good introduction for Portuguese poetry.

The Anarchist Banker by Fernando Pessoa (1922) French title: Le banquier anarchiste. Translated from the Portuguese by Fran√ßoise Laye.

The Anarchist Banker by Fernando Pessoa is a novella in which a banker explains to his audience why he is a true anarchist. It has been on my TBW (To Be Written) since April. Why? Mostly because I didn‚Äôt know how to write about it. So, it‚Äôs Catch 22. I can‚Äôt write about it properly but if I don‚Äôt, I‚Äôll break my cardinal rule which is ‚Äúwrite about all the books you read‚Äù.

I feel that if I start allowing myself to skip a billet, other books will be left behind as well. Where does that leave me? I still can‚Äôt write a passable billet about The Anarchist Banker but I can‚Äôt procrastinate anymore.

Solution? A short cut.

Read this witty, incredible novella where a banker will demonstrate with a lot of self-assurance that he is the only genuine anarchist in the world. If anarchist banker wasn‚Äôt such an oxymoron, the reader could believe in the banker‚Äôs reasoning.

He demonstrates that anarchism is a good system but since it‚Äôs impossible to implement, in the end the only possible system is the bourgeois system.

Pessoa has a fantastic sense of humour. His tone is both light and serious, the man totally convinced by his brilliant reasoning. He‚Äôs so ridiculous in his beliefs that it enhances the comedy of situation. This is something that could have been written by a philosophe from the Age of Enlightenment, like Montesquieu.

It is also a fascinating book to read when you think about politics and politicians. It makes you realize how a politician can convince you of something, step by step. He unfolds a reasoning in which each step holds some truth, he asks you to validate each step and one step after the other, he leads you to a path you would never have followed if you‚Äôd seen the whole journey on the map right from the start. It‚Äôs subtle and frightening and we‚Äôve all heard politicians start with an assertion you cannot refute and then build something totally fallacious from it.

That‚Äôs what could happen to the reader here if the constant irony wasn‚Äôt a lifeline that reminds you that this reasoning is flawed.

The Anarchist Banker is also a masterful demonstration of how an idea can become the roots of a dictatorship, how radical changes in a society cannot be implemented because it‚Äôs impossible to do so everywhere at the same time and successfully. So the new system must be forcefed to the population and only an authoritative system can do it.

I really can‚Äôt tell you more about The Anarchist Banker. I highly recommend it as a masterpiece of literature but also as an educational read about all those politicians who want to attract voters through simplistic thinking.

Your Face Will Be the Last by Jo√£o Ricardo Pedro (2012) French title: La main de Joseph Castorp. Translated from the Portuguese by Elisabeth Monteiro Rodrigues.

I‚Äôm a little embarrassed with this billet. Your Face Will Be the Last by Jo√£o Ricardo Pedro is not available in English. The original is in Portuguese and it‚Äôs been translated into French, Dutch and Italian. If anyone stumbling upon this entry has read it, please leave a comment and let me know what you thought about it. Because I‚Äôm totally baffled by it.

Jo√£o Ricardo Pedro throws us head first in a family history. It opens with a murder in an isolated village in Portugal. Celestino is found dead and his friend, the doctor Augusto Mendes recalls how Celestino came to the village decades before. From there we wander into the doctor‚Äôs family tree and the history of Portugal. We discover how he came to live in this isolated village and how he met his wife, we hear about his son Antoni√≥ and his wife, his grandson Duarte. We go back and forth between the village and Lisbon. We are rolled around from one decade to the other with no real way to understand where we are apart from some light clues about Duarte‚Äôs age or an allusion to a historical event. Or maybe there are clues obvious to a Portuguese reader that I totally missed.

It left me puzzled, unable to set the story straight in chronological order in my head. On top of that, there‚Äôs a mystery around Duarte‚Äôs love for the piano, weird friendships and a vague link to Austria. I was totally lost.

Sure, the novel mentions major political events for Portugal in the 20th century. We guess that this family has been hit by the Salazar dictatorship (Duarte‚Äôs mother never talks about her dead parents) and has been deeply affected by the long colonial war in Angola. But it‚Äôs so messy that I got lost. I felt like walking in circle in a forest with no clue of how to make sense of what I was reading. Duarte is a very strange character that I couldn‚Äôt understand and till the end, I remained outside of the book, reading with a mind hovering over what I was reading but never immersed in the story. I never felt I was there with the characters but still wanted to know how it would end.

Don‚Äôt get me wrong, it‚Äôs a good novel from a literary point of view, it just didn‚Äôt work for me. It left me with the disagreeable feeling that I missed a major clue to understand it all. So I‚Äôd be grateful for explanations from readers who have read it. It‚Äôs almost German Lit Month, so Licht, mehr Licht, please!

The Memorables by L√≠dia Jorge (2014) French title: Les M√©morables. Translated by Genevi√®ve Leibrich.

Elle serrait contre elle la copie des plans dessin√©s par la main de celui qui, trente ans plus t√¥t, avait mis en marche cinq mille hommes contre un r√©gime d√©cr√©pit, un de ces r√©gimes si long et si s√©niles qu‚Äôils laissent du fumier sur la terre pour plusieurs si√®cles. She held to her chest a copy of the maps designed by the man who, thirty years before, had led five thousand men against a decrepit regime. It was one of those long and senile regimes that left manure on earth for several centuries.

‚ÄúShe‚Äù is Ana Maria Machado, a young Portuguese journalist who works for CBS in Washington DC. The five thousand men mentioned in this quote are the military men who participated in the coup d‚Äô√©tat on April 25th, 1974 in Lisbon, the one that led to the Carnation Revolution and the fall of the Portuguese dictatorship.

After reportages in war zones, Ana Maria‚Äôs boss asks her to go back to Lisbon and film a documentary about the Carnation Revolution and the miracle of this peaceful revolution where the military takes power to bring democracy to their country.

Ana Maria is reluctant to go back to Lisbon where she has unresolved issues with her father, √Åntonio Machado, a famous political editorialist whose column always proved to be insightful. He was also close to the people who did the revolution. Ana Maria needs a crew for her mission and rekindles a working relationship with Margarida and Miguel √Çngelo, two reporters she knew in journalism school.

Ana Maria decides against telling her father about her project, mostly because she doesn‚Äôt want him to interfere with her vision of the events. In √Åntonio‚Äôs office, she borrows a picture taken on 21st of August 1975, in a restaurant, the Memories. This picture portrays all the people who were decisive participants in the revolution and close witnesses of the events. This photo will be the Ariadne thread of the documentary.

Ana Maria and her friends want to reconstruct the minutes this 25 of April 1974 and understand what everyone did and when. They will go and interview these key actors or their widow to discover what they did that day, how they felt, how they lived afterwards and how they reflect on the revolution, thirty years later.

L√≠dia Jorge autopsies the military coup that brought democracy to her country but more importantly, she questions what happened to the major players of the Carnation Revolution. Her book was published in 2014, for the fortieth anniversary of the 25 of April 1974 events. Ana Maria writes her story six years after she did her documentary and what she narrates happened in 2004, for the thirtieth anniversary of the revolution. Symbolic years. Time and remembrance are important in her book.

I wanted to read about the Carnation Revolution and it gave me a better vision of what happened and how extraordinary it was to have such a smooth transition to democracy. L√≠dia Jorge points out two disconcerting facts about these events: one, the major actors of the military coup were never properly thanked and none had a glorious career after that. And two, they were forgotten from the public. This is very different from what Petros Markaris describes about Greece in Bread, Education, Freedom or what Yasmina Khadra writes about Algeria in Dead Man‚Äôs Share. Both Markaris and Khadra explain how the actors of the country‚Äôs liberation cashed on their being on the right side, either during the decisive demonstration against the Greek regime or against the French. In these two countries, these men became untouchable heroes, grabbed on power and didn‚Äôt let it go.

According to The Memorables, no heroes were born from the Carnation Revolution in Portugal. Ana Maria knew the men on the photo because her parents gravitated in their circle. Margarida and Miguel √Çngelo had to research them. L√≠dia Jorge wants to celebrate them, to remind them to the Portuguese and show how ungrateful the Republic was towards them. None of them benefited from their act.

In addition to the questioning about the place they have in the Portuguese collective memory, L√≠dia Jorge muses over the impact of living through such historical events.
